Qin Hongwei ⁎ , Muldowney Michelle, Reynolds Stephanie, Yanagisawa Lora, Benveniste Etty Department of Cell Biology, University of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, United States Macrophages and microglia are central players in the development and progression of inflammatory diseases in the Central Nervous System (CNS), such as Multiple Sclerosis (MS), Alzheimer's Disease and HIV-associated Neurocognitive Disorders. Suppressor Of Cytokine Signaling (SOCS) proteins are critical feedback inhibitors of the JAK/ STAT signaling pathway, and negatively regulate innate and adaptive immune responses. Our previous studies indicated that SOCS1 and SOCS3 proteins negatively influence the chemotaxis of macrophages and CD4+ T cells. Experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), the animal model of MS, is used as a model to study the function of SOCS3 in neuroinflammation.

back_matter.text: We have determined the monomer-oligomer state of nucleophosmin by Western blot and its localization by immunocytochemistry. Besides monoclonal antibodies (FC82291, Sigma) that recognize both nucleophosmin monomers and oligomers, we used our original antipeptide antibodies which specifically react either oligomers or monomers. We have analyzed the state of B23 in various human tumor cells such as HeLa, Hep G2, MCF-7, NGP, K-562, Jurkat, Ramos, U-87, JMR-32; in rat tumor C6 cells, normal rat tissues (brain, liver, kidney, heart, lung). The SDS-stable oligomers were detected in all tumor cells, but were not detected in normal tissue cell lysates, excluding brain.Analysis of B23 in different compartments of rat brain, including cerebellum, stem, hippocampus, cortex, amygdala as well as in primary culture of cerebellar glia cells, showed different proportion of monomers and oligomers in the examined compartment, and also demonstrated that glia cells contained mainly B23 oligomers. We revealed essential differences in the level and localization of oligomers and monomers in glioma (C6, U-87) and neuroblastoma JMR-32 cells. This work was supported by the Basic Sciences to Medicine Foundation (project 2009-2011) and by the Russian Foundation for Basic Research (project 09-04-00713).

Martin-Blondel Guillaume ⁎ ,1 , Bauer Jan 2 , Marchou Bruno 3 Report a case series of 18 consecutive neuro-IRIS and infer the pathophysiology of this emergent neurological inflammatory disease in HIV-infected patients treated with antiretroviral therapy (ART).Retrospective analysis of all opportunistic infections (OI) affecting the CNS during a ten-year period in HIV-infected patients followed in the infectious and tropical diseases department of the Toulouse University Hospital.Among 125 OI of the CNS (65 toxoplasmic encephalitis (TE), 38 JC virus-induced progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), 20 cryptococcosis and 2 tuberculosis), 18 fulfilled criteria for either paradoxical or unmasking neuro-IRIS. The diagnoses were PML in 10 cases, cryptococcosis in 5 cases and TE in 3 cases. Four patients with PML-IRIS deceased with a median survival time of 3.9 months (2.5-112) .The pathophysiology of neuro-IRIS seems to be multifactorial. Among several pathogens associated with OI of the CNS, only intracellular pathogens such as JC virus, Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Cryptococcus neoformans and Toxoplasma gondii, are associated with neuro-IRIS development. Tuberculosis was underestimated in our study due to low endemicity of this pathogen in high-income countries. Genetic factors involved in anti-infectious immune responses might also predispose to IRIS. The excessive tissue inflammation that follows immune restoration is favoured by the defects observed in immune regulation mechanisms. Lymphopenia-induced proliferation and numerical and/or functional defects in regulatory T-cells might compromise the mechanisms that normally serve to maintain host tolerance, thereby favouring the initiation and the exacerbation of the immune response underlying neuro-IRIS. Tools to quantify and enumerate pathogen-specific immune cells prior and during ART should be very useful in improving the diagnosis and in predicting IRIS development. Novel therapeutic strategies that selectively alleviate inflammation without blunting immune restoration are warranted. In that respect, the combined antiviral and immunomodulatory characteristics of maraviroc, antagonist of the chemokine receptor CCR5, make it an attractive therapeutic approach that meets these requirements.
back_matter.section: Immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome affecting the CNS (neuro-IRIS) during HIV infection: New insights on its pathophysiology from a case series

back_matter.text: Intermittentt plasmapheresis prevents recurrence in neuromyelitis optica

Kinki University School of Medicine, Osaka-Sayama, JapanNeuromyelitis optica (NMO) is a relapsing inflammatory characterized by selective involvement of the optic nerves and spinal cord. Humoral immune mechanisms play a role in the pathogenesis of NMO. The therapeutic efficacy of plasmapheresis (PP) has been reported in the cases that were poorly controlled with other treatments. Herein, we report four patients with NMO who underwent PP following intensive intravenous corticosteroid therapy.All patients showed definite functional improvement following one to five plasma exchanges. To prevent relapse, these patients were treated with oral prednisolone in combination with azathioprine or cyclophosphamide. Two of four patients also underwent intermittent PP because the treatment with oral agents was unsuccessful.In conclusion, when treatment with oral immunosuppressants is ineffective to reduce recurrences of NMO an additional PP should be attempted.

Natalizumab treatment on Multiple Sclerosis patients: Effects on regulatory T cells and cytokine serum levels Ramos-Cejudo Jaime ⁎ ,2 , Oreja-Guevara Celia 1 , Stark Luiz 2 , Gabaldón Torres L. 1 Natalizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody widely used for Multiple Sclerosis treatment. The antibody specifically binds to the VLA-4 antigen and inhibits T cell entry into the brain through diminishing extravasations at the endothelium. However, little is known about full biological effects of Natalizumab treatment on regulatory T cell activity and cytokine production. Our goal was to evaluate the longitudinal effects of Natalizumab on regulatory T cell activity and Th1/Th2 cytokine serum levels in Relapsing-Remitting Multiple Sclerosis patients.22 patients matched in sex and ages were included in a longitudinal exploratory study. Blood samples were obtained at baseline, at 2 hours, at 4 and 15 days, and also 1, 2, 5-6 and 9-12 months later. Patients underwent a complete neurological examination (EDSS) and cranial MRI every six months. CD4+ CD25hi FoxP3 + regulatory T cells were isolated from additional fresh blood samples obtained at baseline and one month later using Miltenyi Biotech purification Kit. Activity was determined as suppression of T cells proliferation previously stimulated with anti-CD3 and anti-CD28. Levels of Th1 and Th2-related cytokines (IL-1a, IL-2, IL-4, IL-5, IL-6, IL-8, IL-10, IL-12p70, IL-13, MCP-1, TGF and INF-gamma) were determined by Cytometric Bead Array. Samples were always obtained before intravenous infusion. Natalizumab was globally well tolerated. We did not found any significant association in regulatory T cell activity or frequency in the followed cohort of patients. Treated patients showed significant higher values of Th1 / Th2-related cytokines just few hours or days after the first IV-infusion (INFgamma and IL-5, p b 0.01; IL-12, p b 0.001, IL-4 and IL-10, p b 0.01). One year after starting treatment, some cytokines presented elevated levels, such us IL-1b, IL-2, IL-5 and IL-13 (p b 0.001).We have found increased serum levels of both Th1 and Th2-related cytokines just after first IV-infusions of Natalizumab. Globally, levels of cytokines tend to increase in response to treatment and some of them maintained elevated after one year. We observed no effects on frequency or activity of regulatory T cells. Although unclear, our results might have a relationship with undesirable adverse effects of Natalizumab.

Pattern of mild cognitive impairment in patients with primary Sjögren's syndrome as compared to patients with SLE Maroni Stian Stangeland 3 , Brønnick Kolbjørn 1 , Harboe Erna 2 , Gøransson Lasse G 2 , Omdal Roald 2 Brain tumors and human brain tumor-derived cell lines are characterized by enhanced cell surface expression levels of interleukin (IL) 4 and 13 receptors. In addition, polymorphisms in the IL4 receptor gene are associated with survival rates of patients with glioblastoma, further suggesting that IL4-mediated signaling plays a role in the pathogenesis. This prompted us to study the effects of IL4 on the immune functions of microglia, the resident antigen presenting cells (APCs) of the brain.Primary microglia that were exposed to IL4 acquired an expression profile of cell surface molecules reminiscent of dendritic cells (DC), i.e. strongly reduced CD14 expression and enhanced expression of CD11c, CD83, CD86 and MHC classII. However, when probed for innate immune responses, these cells did not produce pro-inflammatory cytokines in response to TLR-mediated activation, irrespective of the TLR ligand used. This in marked contrast to primary microglia or monocyte-derived macrophages or DC generated from the same donors. Unexpectedly, NF-kappaB activation and nuclear translocation were found intact upon TLR engagement. We therefore screened for epigenetic alterations in IL4-exposed microglia and revealed that the expression profile of histone deacetylases (HDACs) was dramatically altered. Resetting of the altered HDAC profile by a targeted siRNA approach partially restored TLR-responsiveness. In situ analysis of a variety of brain tumors demonstrated that microglia in close proximity to the tumor were characterized by an altered expression profile of HDACs that closely resembled the profile we observed in vitro. Interestingly, when IL4-exposed microglia, either naive or TLRprimed, were used as APC in mixed lymphocyte reactions they potently induced the proliferation of Treg cells. Thus brain tumors might indirectly exploit the effects of IL4 on TLR responsiveness and APC function of microglia to suppress or subvert immune responses. Modulation of this pathway might represent an attractive novel therapeutic approach.

Paraneoplastic Yo antibodies are not related to the presence of cerebellar degeneration-associated CDR2 antigen in ovarian cancerTotland Cecilie ⁎ ,1 , Aarskog Nina K. 1 Patients with cancer may develop paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration (PCD) due to humoral and cellular immune responses to the onconeural antigen called cerebellar degeneration-related protein 2 (CDR2). Since the pathogenesis of PCD is largely unknown, we studied whether CDR2 cDNA sequence, mRNA or CDR2 protein levels in primary ovarian cancers were associated with serum antibodies to CDR2 (anti-Yo).We obtained serum samples and corresponding ovarian cancer tissue from 14 patients. Three of the ovarian cancer patients had Yo antibodies. We also studied CDR2 in other tissues. Similar CDR2 mRNA and protein levels were found in the ovarian cancers, as detected by real-time quantitative polymerase chain reaction and immunoblot. cDNA sequencing did not reveal any variants in the CDR2 coding sequence of the 14 ovarian cancers. Immunoblots also demonstrated CDR2 in normal ovarian tissue, in cell lines of ovarian cancer, lung cancer and neuroblastoma, and in normal human cerebellum, but not in human cerebrum. CDR2 was localized to the cytoplasma of the ovarian and lung cancer cell lines, whereas CDR2 was localized to both nucleus and cytoplasm in ovarian and colon cancer biopsies. However, CDR2 was also present on normal ovary stromal and epithelial cells.We found no post-transcriptional regulation of CDR2 in ovarian tissue or ovarian cancer. Furthermore, there was no association between CDR2 cDNA sequence, mRNA or protein level and Yo antibody production in ovarian cancer patients. This suggests that the immune regulation of Yo antibody synthesis is related to antigen presentation and T-cell regulation.

Rapid involvement of arm and bulbar muscles raises suspicion for small cell lung cancer in the Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome In 50% of the patients with the Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) a small cell lung carcinoma (SCLC) can be found. A significant clinical concern is the early detection of these tumors in newly diagnosed LEMS patients. Patients with LEMS and SCLC develop their neuromuscular symptoms more rapidly than non-tumour LEMS patients (NT-LEMS). We studied how this clinical information, which is readily available at the first consultation, can be used to predict the presence of SCLC.We included 219 LEMS patients: 107 Dutch LEMS patients (58 with SCLC), diagnosed between 1990 and 2008, from 1998 prospectively and a second cohort (n = 112, 46 with SCLC-LEMS) was collected in the UK (Oxford and Nottingham) to compare outcomes and external validity. We compared frequency and onset of symptoms early during the disease course of LEMS.Results Between onset of LEMS and three months, all clinical symptoms, neuromuscular and autonomic, were more prevalent in SCLC-LEMS patients than in NT-LEMS patients. Rapid involvement of proximal arm muscles (80% vs 32%), distal arm muscles (47% vs 8%), distal leg muscles (45% vs 10%), bulbar muscles (55% vs 16%), a dry mouth (80% vs 40%) and the presence of male sexual impotence (65% vs 32%) were found significantly more often in SCLC-LEMS patients in both cohorts (p b 0.001 for all symptoms). Cerebellar symptoms, Chronic microglial activation may play a role in the etiopathogenesis of Alzheimer's dementia and other neurodegenerative disorders. A role in modulating microglial activation could be ascribed to the serotoninergic system originating in the raphe nuclei located in the brainstem, which undergoes progressive neuro-degeneration along with amyloid beta (Aβ) plaque accumulation in the cortex of APPswe/ PS1E9 transgenic (Tg) mice as demonstrated by Liu et al. (J Neurosci 28 (51)13805). Our hypothesis is that serotoninergic neurotransmission reduces Aβ-induced microglial activation and Aβ-plaques load in the cortex. Here, we investigated if the serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) Paroxetine, which raises the amount of serotonin in the clefts of serotoninergic synapses in the cortex, administered per os to APPswe/ PS1E9 Tg and wildtype (Wt) mice over a period of 3 months, would be able to reduce Aβ-induced microglial activation and Aβ-plaque load in the cortex.APPswe/PS1E9 Tg and Wt mice were treated with Paroxetine (10 mg/kg) or vehicle (water) from 9 to 12 month of age. Monthly monitoring of drug levels by using mass spectrometry on eye vein samples showed that the levels of Paroxetine in serum were in the upper range of therapeutic levels (10-500 nM). Body weight and water intake were unaffected by the treatment. To allow monitoring of microglial proliferation, mice were injected with the proliferation marker bromodeoxyuridine 3 times over 24 hours prior to termination with anaesthesia and transcardial perfusion with 10 ml of PBS. The right hemisphere was fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde (PFA) for 24 hours, followed by 1% PFA for 24 hours. Next, the right hemisphere was put in 20% sucrose, frozen, cut into 50 μm thick sections and stored in Olmos solution at −14°C, ready to be stained for Aβ and microglial CDllb and CD45. From the left hemisphere, hippocampus and cortex were processed for ELISA and qPCR for inflammatory markers. The first results show that the mRNA levels of the proinflammatory cytokine TNFa in the cortex is significantly higher in vehicle treated Tg compared to vehicle treated Wt mice at 12 months. The 3 months administration of Paroxetine had no statistically significant effect on TNFa mRNA levels in neither Tg nor Wt mice. Similar results were obtained for cortical levels of IL-1β mRNA.These data, prudently interpreted, indicate that 3 months treatment with Paroxetine has no effect on Aβ-induced microglial cytokine response in APPswe/PS1E9 Tg mice. The monocyte chemoattract protein-1/CCL2 (13 KDa) is a member of the CC chemokine family that acts like a potent quimiotactic factor for monocytes. The interaction with its receptor, CCR2, has been related to the pathogenesis of Multiple Sclerosis (MS). High levels of MCP-1/CCL2 in CSF and actively demyelinating lesions have been detected in patients with MS. Moreover, CCL2-deficient mice have been found to be markedly resistant to the induction of EAE, and the treatments with anti-CCL3 antibodies were efficacious in inhibiting EAE onset. Several studies support the potential therapeutic value of cannabinoids (CBs) in the treatment of MS and its experimental models but advances will be made in reducing CBs side effects, including unwanted psychoactivity. Then, studies with non-psychoactive cannabinoids are needed. Our current research is focusing on the study of cellular and molecular mechanisms involved in the inhibitory effect of CBs in leukocyte entry into the brain. Previous work from the lab has shown that CBs downregulate adhesion molecule expression in Theiler murine encephalomyelitis virusinduced demyelinating disease (TMEV-IDD). Because of the importance of MCP-1 in leukocyte infiltration we investigated in vivo modulation by non-psychotropic CBs like CBD and the cannabinomimetic compound palmitoylethanolamide (PEA) in TMEV-IDD.Our results showed a different expression profile of MCP-1/CCL2 and CCR2 during TMEV-IDD development (3, 7, 21, 35, 60, 90, 180 days post-infection) . Treatment with the non-psychoactive CBD at earlier stages diminishes MCP-1/CCL2 expression and reduces clinical score of TMEV-IDD. Our next step was to analyze the effects of CBD and PEA on the interaction of CCL2-CCR2 using an in vitro BBB model and its consequences in leukocytes infiltration. Our preliminary results showed that CBD decreases MCP-1 induced by TNFalpha/IL-1betha in astrocytes cultures.These results support the interest of using non-psychoactive cannabinoids as potential therapeutic agents in MS.

Novel mechanism for Herpes simplex virus type-1 entry identified by positional cloning Diez Margarita ⁎ ,1 , Bereczky-Veress Biborka 1 , Abdelmagid Nada 1 , Bergström Tomas 2 , Sköldenberg Birgit 1 , Piehl Fredrik 1 , Olsson Tomas 1 1 Karolinska Institutet, Stockholm, Sweden; 2 Göteborg University, Göteborg, SwedenHerpes simplex encephalitis (HSE) is caused by Herpes simplex virus-1. Around 2-4 individuals/million/year are affected by HSE. It is characterized by severe focal brain inflammation and neurodegeneration. The contribution of a genetic component that regulates susceptibility to HSE, was identified by injecting human HSV-1 into the whiskers' area of DA and PVG.1AV1 inbred rat strains. Results show that DA rats were highly susceptible to HSE whereas the PVG.1AV1 strain is resistant. The model resembles the natural propagation of HSV-1 in humans; spreading from the lips via the trigeminal nerve to trigeminal ganglia and subsequently entering the central nervous system (CNS) to induce encephalitis.In the whiskers area, nerve endings were infected in both susceptible and resistant strain, however, differences of virus transport and replication in the host nerves and in the perineurial cells surrounding the nerve bundle were seen. In the susceptible DA rat, perineurial cells support replication and promote further spread to the trigeminal ganglia whereas in the resistant PVG.1AV1, these cells do not support the infection and therefore hamper the disease. Differences in the innate immune response and of Tlr2 and -9 expression were also observed.To identify the gene(s) regulating HSE, an F2 (DAxPVG.1AV1) was made. The individuals were challenged with HSV-1, resulting in a An interrelation of the two major hallmarks in sporadic inclusion body myositis (sIBM)-muscle, inflammation and b-amyloid-associated degeneration, has recently been described. The molecular basis of these interactions has so far remained elusive and is addressed in this study: High mobility group box 1 (HMGB1), a transcriptional factor and "alarmin", has been demonstrated during skeletal muscle regeneration. Its receptor for advanced glycation endproducts (RAGE) is relevant to bamyloid associated cell stress in Alzheimer's dementia.Muscle biopsies of patients with sIBM (n = 10), muscular dystrophy (n = 6) or healthy controls (n = 8) were studied. HMGB1-/RAGE-expression was analyzed by real time-PCR. Protein expression and co-localization to b-amyloid and tau/SMI-31 was detected by double-label immunohistochemistry of serial sections. Human primary myotubes and myoblasts were exposed to combinations of IL-1b, IFN-g, TNF-a, recombinant HMGB1 or BoxA peptide for 24 to 72 hours. HMGB1-/RAGE-expression and cell death were analyzed by real time-PCR, immunocytochemistry and/or FACS. Extracellular HMGB1 was quantified by ELISA. Amyloid-deposits and cell death were detected by thioflavin-S staining.On the levels of mRNA and protein, a significant overexpression of HMGB1 and RAGE was observed in sIBM-muscle compared to controls. Quantitative multi-parameter analysis of serially stained fibers revealed a significant co-localization of HMGB1 with RAGE as well as with accumulations of degeneration-associated molecules such as b-amyloid and tau/SMI-31. Upon exposure of muscle cells to a combination of IL-1b and IFN-g, HMGB1 entirely translocated from the nucleus into the cytoplasm and, as evidenced by ELISA of the supernatant, was significantly released. At the same time, an upregulation of the surface expression of RAGE was observed by immunocytochemistry and FACS. Compared to IL-1b + IFN-g, recombinant HMGB1 was equally potent in inducing intracellular accumulation of b-amyloid and subsequent cell death of muscle cells. The HMGB1 inhibitor BoxA significantly reduced accumulation of b-amyloid and cell death induced either by IFN-g + IL-1b or exogenous HMBG1.The data further our understanding of sIBM pathology and underscore that unique interactions between degenerative and inflammatory mechanisms are relevant. Our data suggest that in the network of sIBM pathomechanisms, signaling by HMGB1/RAGE is pivotal and may be efficiently targeted by inhibitors such as BoxA.

The roles of Nogo receptor-mediated interactions in autoimmune inflammation in experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis The myelin-proteins Nogo-A and MAG are considered important inhibitors of nerve regeneration in the adult central nervous system (CNS) via Nogo receptor (NgR)-mediated interactions. Blocking strategies targeting this pathway have been successfully applied in several nerve injury models, suggesting Nogo-A and functionally related proteins like LINGO-1 as therapeutic targets to enhance regeneration in multiple sclerosis (MS). Especially anti-Nogo-A strategies have ameliorated the clinical outcome of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), the established animal model of MS. However, whether and to what extent NgR-signaling is involved in mediating Nogo-A-related inhibition of neuroregeneration is currently under debate. To address this issue, we examined a potential function of NgR-mediated interactions on autoimmune CNS inflammation and regeneration of the damaged CNS.We induced EAE in NgR1−/−, NgR2−/− and NgR1/2 doubledeficient mice, but did not observe a pronounced effect of NgR1-or NgR2-deficiency on the clinical outcome of EAE. Nevertheless, the composition of infiltrating immune cells was significantly changed in NgR1/2 double-deficient mice compared to wildtype littermate controls. Interestingly, an additional role besides inhibition of nerve regeneration has recently been described for NgR-mediated interactions on leukocyte trafficking into injured nervous tissue. Therefore, we investigated whether Nogo receptors or Nogo receptor ligands are expressed in the immune system, and how NgR-mediated interactions contribute to the inflammatory response in autoimmune CNS inflammation.The results of these studies will be discussed in the context of NgR-NgR-ligand interactions in the CNS versus the immune system. Blood-derived myeloid cells account for a significant proportion of the leukocytes found within perivascular infiltrates in CNS lesions of multiple sclerosis (MS) and its animal model, experimental allergic encephalomyelitis (EAE). These antigen-presenting cells (APCs) are thought to be pivotal in the initiation and perpetuation of the CNStargeted immune response in MS and EAE by promoting the reactivation of myelin-reactive T lymphocytes and by inducing tissue damage through the release of neurotoxic factors. However, the exact molecules that direct the trafficking of myeloid cells into the CNS remain largely unknown. Our goal was thus to identify the adhesion molecules that would specifically and exclusively inhibit the recruitment of myeloid cells into the CNS without affecting other leukocyte subsets, to minimize the occurrence of serious adverse events reported with the use of broad-spectrum adhesion molecule blockers.We identified nerve injury-induced protein-1 (Ninjurin-1) in a proteomic screen of human blood-brain barrier (BBB)-associated Workshops Department of Pathology and Diagnostics, Division of General Pathology, University of Verona, Verona, ItalyPantethine is the stable disulfate form of pantetheine, the metabolic substrate that constitutes the active part of coenzyme A molecules (CoA) and acyl carrier proteins (ACP). Pantethine has been tested in humans for its lipid lowering activity and, importantly, no collateral effects were reported. Recent data showed that treatment with pantethine delayed the occurrence of cerebral malaria in a mouse model, with down-regulation of key cellular responses to the inflammatory cerebral syndrome and reduction of blood-brain barrier (BBB) breakdown. The aim of this study was to investigate the effect of pantethine on experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), the animal model of Multiple Sclerosis (MS).In vivo experiments using C57Bl/6J and SJL mice demonstrated that pantethine prevents the development of chronic and relapsingremitting EAE by delaying the disease onset and reducing the clinical score. Neuropathological studies showed a decrease in inflammatory cell infiltrates and demyelination in mice treated with pantethine. Also, T cells isolated from draining lymph nodes of mice treated with pantethine showed a significant reduction in the antigen-specific proliferation and pro-inflammatory cytokine production when compared to cells from untreated mice. By using IVIS 200 system we found that treatment of mice with pantethine reduced BBB leakage in the spinal cord, the main site of central nervous system inflammation, in the preclincal phase of EAE. Moreover, pre-treatment of T cells with pantethine blocked encephalitogenic T cells, but not naïve lymphocyte, adhesion to purified integrin ligands in vitro. No effect was observed on adhesion molecule expression and integrin distribution in clusters on the cell membrane, suggesting that pantethine may reduce T cell adhesion by inhibiting the signal transduction machinery required for integrin affinity triggering. Finally, intravital microscopy experiments performed in inflamed brain vessels showed that pretreatment of encephalitogenic T cells with pantethine has a significant inhibitory effect on firm adhesion interactions.Our results demonstrate that metabolic intervention with pantethine has immuno-modulatory effects on EAE by reducing T cell activation and adhesiveness and protecting BBB. Since pantethine has low cost and has been successfully administered in humans with absence of side effects, further studies are warranted to obtain indication on the potential clinical usage of pantethine in MS. The presence of oligoclonal bands of IgG (OCB) in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is used to establish a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis (MS), but their specificity has remained an enigma since its first description over forty years ago. Hypothesising that OCBs might react with heteromeric lipid complexes we created arrays of 10 myelin lipids and all their 1:1 combinations, comprising 55 antigens. We sought serum and CSF IgG anti-complex antibodies in 40 MS and 40 patients with other neurological disease (OND).

Heatmap analysis identified a lipid specific CSF antibody response in MS patients that preferentially targeted sulfatide (p = 0.004; ANOVA with Bonferroni) and heterodimeric complexes of sulfatide with other lipids. Within individual CSF samples, antibody binding was modulated by specific lipid partnerships. Lipid reactive antibodies were detected in 60% of MS CSF and 25% OND CSF. This MS response was mostly unaccompanied by a serum response indicating that the response was intrathecal and might represent OCB specifities. To explore this, we assessed 100 recombinant antibodies (rAb) derived from clonally expanded CSF B cells/plasmablasts obtained from patients with MS (n = 11; 73 rAb) and other CNS inflammatory diseases (OIND; n = 6; 27 rAb). Lipid specific rAb were generated from 45% of MS patients and accounted for 27% (20/73) of the total rAb, of which 14 bound sulfatide and/or sulfatide containing complexes. The patterns obtained using individual rAb were similar to array patterns probed with CSF from unrelated MS patients, indicating these anti-lipid antibodies represent common, dominant components of this intrathecal response. These specificities were not unique for MS as lipid reactive rAb were also recovered from clonally expanded CSF B cells isolated from OIND patients ( 9/27 rAb; 33%).As sulfatide provides a target for demyelinating antibodies in experimental animals, anti-sulfatide titres have been assumed to be pathogenic. Our preliminary data indicate otherwise, as unlike the demyelinating antibody O4, the sulfatide reactive rAbs fail to bind to the surface of live myelin or oligodendrocytes in vitro; an effect associated with a marked difference in the fine specificity of these antibodies. This suggests that sulfatide-containing complexes recognized by these rAb are not normally accessible within the plane of the living membrane and are unlikely to provide targets for primary antibody-mediated demyelination. Subacute cerebellar ataxia may have an autoimmune aetiology in some patients. Paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration can be associated with onconeural and calcium channel (VGCC) antibodies, and some non-paraneoplastic cerebellar syndromes are positive for GAD or Homer-3 antibodies. However, proof of an autoantibody-mediated mechanism is lacking as most of these antibodies react with intracellular antigens and are probably biomarkers of an immune process rather than being pathogenic. However, we hypothesized that some patients would have an immune-mediated syndrome associated with autoantibodies to a cell surface antigen, and we screened a cohort of patients with possible autoimmune cerebellar syndromes for cerebellar neurons surface antigens antibodies.Fifty-six serum samples from four European centers were collected. Indirect immunofluorescence on live cultured rat cerebellar granule neurons (CGNs) and live cerebellar organotypic slices were used for primary screening. Immunoprecipitation and mass spectrometry were performed to identify the antigenic target. Cell-based immunofluorescence assays (CBA) were performed with possible candidate antigens.Twelve out of 56 samples exhibited reactivity on live CGNs or organotypic cerebellar slices showing binding to the surface of neurons. A proteomic approach (IP plus Mass Spec) led to the identification of Caspr-
